title: Low Risk: Chest Pain Obs (Cardiology)
description: 45F with atypical chest pain. Stable vitals, negative cardiac enzymes. Discharged home with outpatient follow-up.
text:
DISCHARGE SUMMARY

PATIENT NAME: [REDACTED]
MRN: [REDACTED]
ADMISSION DATE: [DATE]
DISCHARGE DATE: [DATE]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
45-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presented to the ED complaining of chest discomfort. She describes the pain as a dull, non-radiating pressure in the center of her chest, starting 4 hours prior to arrival while sitting at REST. No associated diaphoresis, nausea, or shortness of breath. She denies recent travel, calf pain, or sick contacts.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Hypertension, controlled on Lisinopril.
2. Hyperlipidemia.
3. GERD.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Gen: Alert, oriented x3, no acute distress.
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1/S2, no murmurs/rubs/gallops.
Resp: CTAB, no wheezes/crackles. RR 16, SpO2 98% on RA.
Abd: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.
Ext: No edema, 2+ pulses radially and dorsalis pedis.

VITALS AT ADMISSION:
Heart Rate: 78
BP: 122/76
Resp Rate: 16
Temp: 36.8 C
SpO2: 98%

PERTINENT LABS:
WBC: 7.4
Hgb: 13.2
Hct: 39.8
Plt: 240
Na: 139
K: 4.2
Cr: 0.8
BUN: 14
Glucose: 102

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted for observation to rule out ACS. Serial troponins remained negative. A nuclear stress test was performed the following morning and showed no evidence of ischemia or prior scar. EF estimated at 60%. Her chest pain resolved with GI cocktail, suggesting GERD etiology.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
Stable. Chest pain resolved.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
1. Lisinopril 10mg daily.
2. Atorvastatin 20mg daily.
3. Pantoprazole 40mg daily.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:
Discharged to Home. Follow up with PCP in 1 week and Cardiology in 2 weeks.

title: Moderate Risk: COPD Exacerbation (Internal Medicine)
description: 68M smoker with COPD/DM2/HTN. Admitted for dyspnea/pneumonia. Treated with abx/steroids. Moderate utilizer.
text:
DISCHARGE SUMMARY

PATIENT IDENTIFICATION: 68-year-old male.

CHIEF COMPLAINT: Shortness of breath, productive cough.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. [NAME] is a 68yo male with significant PMH of COPD (on 2L home O2), T2DM, and HTN who presents with 3 days of worsening dyspnea and increased sputum production (yellow/green). He reports using his rescue inhaler q2h with minimal relief. He also notes subjective fevers and chills. No chest pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
- COPD (FEV1 45% predicted)
- T2DM (A1c 8.2%)
- Hypertension
- CKD Stage 2

UTILIZATION HISTORY:
ED visits in last 6 months: 2
Admissions in last 12 months: 2

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
General: Dyspneic, speaking in short sentences. Using accessory muscles.
Lungs: Diffuse expiratory wheezes bilaterally. RLL crackles noted.
Heart: Tachycardic, regular.
Extremities: Trace pitting edema bilaterally.

VITAL SIGNS:
HR: 96
BP: 148/88
RR: 24
Temp: 37.8 C
SpO2: 91% on 4L NC (baseline 2L)

LABORATORY DATA:
WBC: 14.5
Hgb: 11.4
Plt: 280
Na: 134
K: 4.9
BUN: 31
Cr: 1.5
Glucose: 182
HCO3: 20

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Patient admitted for COPD exacerbation triggered by CAP. Started on Ceftriaxone/Azithromycin, IV Methylprednisolone (transitioned to Prednisone taper), and scheduled Duonebs. Oxygen requirement improved back to baseline 2L over 4 days. Blood sugars controlled with sliding scale insulin.

DISCHARGE PLAN:
Complete 7-day course of antibiotics. Finish steroid taper. Continue home O2.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:
Home with Home Health support (VNA for nursing/PT).
Condition: Improved.

title: High Risk: Decompensated Heart Failure (Complex)
description: 75M with HFrEF, CKD, AFib. Volume overload, AKI, hypoxia. High utilizer (4 ED visits/6mo). Discharged to SNF.
text:
DISCHARGE SUMMARY

ADMIT DIAGNOSIS: Acute Decompensated Heart Failure, Acute Kidney Injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
75yo M with known HFrEF (EF 25%), CKD IV, Chronic AFib (on Warfarin), and COPD admitted with 1 week of progressive orthopnea (sleeping in recliner), PND, and 15lb weight gain. He reports he ran out of his Lasix 5 days ago. Presented to ED with severe air hunger.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
- Heart Failure (HFrEF)
- CKD Stage 4 (baseline Cr 1.9)
- Atrial Fibrillation
- COPD
- Obstructive Sleep Apnea

UTILIZATION:
4 ED visits in past 6 months.
3 admissions in 12 months.
Last admission: 18 days ago (for similar complaints).

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Gen: Obese male in moderate respiratory distress.
Neck: JVP elevated to angle of jaw.
CV: Irregularly irregular, rate 110s. 3/6 systolic murmur.
Lungs: Diffuse crackles 2/3 up fields.
Ext: 3+ pitting edema to knees. Chronic venous stasis changes.

VITALS:
HR: 118
BP: 168/98
RR: 28
Temp: 37.0
SpO2: 88% on RA -> 94% on 4L
Weight: 92 kg

LABS:
Na: 129
K: 5.6
BUN: 68
Cr: 2.8
Hgb: 9.8
WBC: 8.2

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Admitted to Telemetry. Aggressive diuresis with IV Furosemide drip. Diltiazem drip for rate control, transitioned to oral. Net negative 8L over 5 days. AKI worsened initially (Cr 3.1) then improved to 2.2. Potassium managed medically. Physical therapy evaluated and recommended sub-acute rehab due to deconditioning and frequent falls at home.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
- Furosemide 80mg BID
- Carvedilol 12.5mg BID
- Warfarin (dosed by sensation)
- Lisinopril held due to AKI

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:
Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF) for rehabilitation.
Risk of Readmission: High.

title: Critical: Sepsis Bounce-back (7-day Readmit)
description: 71M readmitted 5 days post-discharge with Urosepsis and Hypotension. ICU stay. Very high risk.
text:
DISCHARGE SUMMARY

PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS: Sepsis secondary to UTI / Pyelonephritis.
SECONDARY: AKI, Hyperglycemia, Encephalopathy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
71-year-old male with history of BPH with chronic indwelling foley, T2DM, and recent admission (discharged 5 days ago for CHF exacerbation) presents with altered mental status and fever. Wife reports he became confused and lethargic this morning. Foley bag showing cloudy urine.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
- BPH w/ obstruction
- T2DM
- CHF
- CKD III
- Recent hospitalization (5 days ago)

VITALS ON ARRIVAL:
Temp: 39.4 C
HR: 122
BP: 84/52
RR: 26
SpO2: 90%

PERTINENT LABS:
WBC: 22.0
Cr: 2.9
Glucose: 342

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Patient admitted to ICU for septic shock. Required central line and Norepinephrine support for 24 hours. Resuscitated with 3L crystalloid. Started on Meropenem for ESBL coverage. Mental status improved by day 3. AKI resolved to Cr 1.8. Foley changed. Endocrine consulted for blood sugar management (started Basal-Bolus insulin).

SOCIAL:
Lives with wife. Needs assistance with ADLs.

DISCHARGE PLAN:
Complete 14-day course of Ertapenem (arranged via PICC line / OPAT).
Home Health Nursing to manage IV antibiotics and foley care.
Close follow-up with Urology.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:
Home with Home Health Services.
Prognosis: Guarded. High risk for re-admission.

title: Pediatric: Asthma Exacerbation
description: 8yo Female with acute asthma attack. Treated with bronchodilators/steroids. Short stay.
text:
DISCHARGE SUMMARY

PATIENT: 8-year-old female.
DIAGNOSIS: Status Asthmaticus, Acute Exacerbation.

HISTORY:
Patient is an 8yo F with history of moderate persistent asthma presented to ED with 1 day of worsening wheezing not responsive to home albuterol. URI symptoms for 2 days. No prior intubations. 1 ICU admission last year.

EXAM:
Gen: Alert, anxious, speaking in single words.
Resp: Diffuse expiratory wheezing, subcostal retractions. Poor air entry at bases.
CV: Tachycardic, regular.

VITALS:
HR: 145
RR: 38
SpO2: 88% RA -> 94% on NRB
Temp: 37.2

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Received 3 continuous albuterol aerosols, IV Magnesium, and IV Solu-Medrul in ED. Admitted to PICU for monitoring. Weaned to q2h then q4h treatments over 48 hours. Steroids transitioned to oral Prednisolone.

DISCHARGE MEDS:
- Albuterol HFA 2 puffs q4h prn
- Prednisolone 20mg daily x 3 days
- Fluticasone daily

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:
Home with parents. Follow up with Pediatrician in 2 days.
